topic: Author‚Äôs Purpose and Style in Writing

definitions.title: Author
definitions.definition: An author is a person who writes a book, article, poem, or any literary work.
definitions.example: Example: J.K. Rowling is the author of the Harry Potter series.
definitions.explanation: The author is the creator of written content whose ideas, tone, and style shape how the reader understands the message.

definitions.title: Author‚Äôs Purpose
definitions.definition: The author‚Äôs purpose is the reason why the author writes ‚Äî to inform, entertain, or persuade.
definitions.example: Example: A news article aims to inform the reader about recent events.
definitions.explanation: Identifying the author‚Äôs purpose helps readers understand the main intent behind a text.

definitions.title: Tone
definitions.definition: Tone refers to the author‚Äôs attitude or feeling toward the subject of the writing.
definitions.example: Example: 'I can‚Äôt believe you did that!' ‚Äî expresses a tone of disbelief or anger.
definitions.explanation: Tone can be joyful, serious, sarcastic, critical, or hopeful depending on the author‚Äôs word choice and phrasing.

definitions.title: Mood
definitions.definition: Mood is the overall emotional feeling or atmosphere that the author creates for the reader.
definitions.example: Example: A dark and stormy night can create a suspenseful or fearful mood.
definitions.explanation: Mood affects how the reader feels while reading and is shaped by imagery, setting, and tone.

definitions.title: Diction
definitions.definition: Diction refers to the author‚Äôs choice and use of words and phrases in writing.
definitions.example: Example: Using words like 'melancholy' instead of 'sad' creates a more formal tone.
definitions.explanation: Through diction, authors set the tone, mood, and level of formality in their writing.

definitions.title: Writing Techniques
definitions.definition: Writing techniques are methods an author uses to communicate ideas effectively, such as descriptive, narrative, expository, and persuasive writing.
definitions.example: Example: A persuasive essay encourages readers to take action on climate change.
definitions.explanation: Different techniques serve different purposes ‚Äî some explain facts, others tell stories, or influence readers‚Äô opinions.

definitions.title: Descriptive Writing
definitions.definition: Descriptive writing focuses on describing people, places, events, or things in detail.
definitions.example: Example: The golden sunset bathed the ocean in warm light.
definitions.explanation: This technique helps readers visualize scenes vividly using sensory language and imagery.

definitions.title: Narrative Writing
definitions.definition: Narrative writing tells a story with a clear beginning, middle, and end.
definitions.example: Example: A short story about a boy overcoming his fear of the dark.
definitions.explanation: It includes characters, setting, conflict, and plot to engage readers emotionally.

definitions.title: Expository Writing
definitions.definition: Expository writing is used to explain or inform readers about a topic using facts and logical organization.
definitions.example: Example: An article explaining how volcanoes erupt.
definitions.explanation: This type of writing avoids opinions and focuses on presenting information clearly.

definitions.title: Persuasive Writing
definitions.definition: Persuasive writing aims to convince readers to accept a belief or take a specific action.
definitions.example: Example: A campaign encouraging people to get vaccinated.
definitions.explanation: It uses logical arguments, emotional appeals, and strong evidence to influence readers‚Äô opinions or behaviors.
